intro: Acanthophyllum kurdicum, commonly known as the Kurdish thornbush, is a shrub native to the arid regions of the Middle East and Central Asia. It is characterized by its dense, spiny foliage and small, often inconspicuous flowers. The plant is well adapted to harsh, dry environments, with deep root systems that help it survive in nutrient-poor soils. Its leaves are typically small and covered in a waxy cuticle to reduce water loss. Acanthophyllum kurdicum plays a role in stabilizing sandy soils and providing habitat for desert wildlife.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acanthophyllum kurdicum is primarily native to the arid and semi-arid regions of the Middle East and Central Asia. It is found in countries such as Iraq, Iran, Turkey, and parts of the Caucasus. This plant thrives in sandy and rocky soils, often in desert or steppe environments. It is well adapted to withstand extreme temperatures and low precipitation. Its distribution is closely associated with specific ecological zones that provide the necessary conditions for its survival.
